text: TIP SHEET
label: TITLE

text: ON THE RESPONSIBLE
label: HH1

text: USE OF ONLINE
label: HH1

text: CONFERENCING TOOLS
label: HH1

text: TIP SHEET
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH2

text: Recent changes to working conditions have increased the use of online conferencing tools throughout
label: BODY

text: the humanitarian sector. These conferencing technologies are invaluable when face-to-face meetings
label: BODY

text: are impossible, but they also pose a significant information security and data protection risk when
label: BODY

text: not used responsibly. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) Data Protection Office,
label: BODY

text: the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, and the Centre for Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Data have developed this tip sheet to support the responsible use of online conferencing tools by
label: BODY

text: humanitarians around the world.
label: BODY

text: This tip sheet offers:
label: BODY

text: an overview of the risks associated with online conferencing, including unauthorized access
label: BODY

text: to meeting rooms/calls, breaches of confidentiality and data protection, third party retention
label: BODY

text: of conferencing data, and malware or social engineering attacks
label: BODY

text: recommendations to mitigate those risks to help you protect yourself and your organization,
label: BODY

text: maintain security for online conference calls that you initiate, and maintain security for online
label: BODY

text: conferences initiated by persons outside your organization
label: BODY

text: a set of resources for further reading.
label: BODY

text: 1. RISKS
label: HH2

text: Some common risks of online conferencing are unauthorized access, breaches of confidentiality and
label: BODY

text: data protection, third party retention of conferencing data, and malware or social engineering attacks.
label: BODY

text: UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO MEETING ROOMS/CALLS
label: BODY

text: Meeting rooms/online conferences may be accessed by anyone who has the link if password
label: BODY

text: protection or authentication measures are not in place.
label: BODY

text: In cases where links and/or passwords are sent to participants and not changed regularly, they
label: BODY

text: can be reused later to allow participants access to the same meeting room without an invitation.
label: BODY

text: It can be difficult to verify the identity of individuals who don’t usually work remotely and have
label: BODY

text: created new profiles or who join using a mobile phone or landline connection.
label: BODY

text: While many online conferencing tools now use encryption by default, allowing participants
label: BODY

text: to dial in from landlines creates an unencrypted channel that is vulnerable to interception.
label: BODY

text: BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY AND DATA PROTECTION
label: BODY

text: Once someone has gained access to a meeting room/online conference, they can drop in and
label: BODY

text: out of that room and listen in to calls at any time.
label: BODY

text: This can (and often does) happen accidentally, e.g. where someone joins a meeting by mistake
label: BODY

text: or joins a meeting early, interrupting the end of another call.
label: BODY

text: In some cases, this might be a minor inconvenience, in others confidential matters or personal
label: BODY

text: information could be disclosed; in worst-case scenarios, hackers might be able to join calls and
label: BODY

text: eavesdrop.
label: BODY

text: Audio recording is getting easier and some new online conferencing tools include “record”
label: BODY

text: and “transcribe” functions, allowing anyone with access to the meeting, invited or otherwise,
label: BODY

text: to record the conversation.
label: BODY

text: Unauthorized recording and transcription of staff and organizational positions and policies
label: BODY

text: significantly increase the risk of unauthorized disclosure of confidential information.
label: BODY

text: Even screensharing can compromise information, e.g. by sharing the wrong screen.
label: BODY

text: Files that are shared in videoconferencing groups may be downloaded by unauthorized
label: BODY

text: participants.
label: BODY

text: Participants may join online conferences from public places or using (insecure) public Wi-Fi
label: BODY

text: networks, amplifying the risk of unauthorized access to information (e.g. eavesdropping,
label: BODY

text: monitoring by external entities or CCTV, interception of data across insecure networks).
label: BODY

text: Working from home can amplify these risks because so many “smart homes” and connected
label: BODY

text: devices have voice assistants and audio capture capabilities (e.g. TVs, lighting systems, fridges)
label: BODY

text: which may leak conversation without their owner’s knowledge.
label: BODY

text: Some online conferencing tools enable “attention tracking”, which may be used to profile
label: BODY

text: participants without their consent.
label: BODY

text: THIRD PARTY RETENTION OF CONFERENCING DATA
label: BODY

text: Online conferencing tools generate metadata about the event and participants, including
label: BODY

text: date, duration, device IDs, IP addresses, settings and other variables that can reveal private
label: BODY

text: information.
label: BODY

text: Metadata can be combined with other data to profile users and make inferences about their
label: BODY

text: activities and behaviour.
label: BODY

text: Online conferencing tools may also retain content data, such as audio recordings, shared
label: BODY

text: messages and attachments.
label: BODY

text: Metadata and content data retained by third parties can be used in ways that conference
label: BODY

text: participants are not aware of and/or would not consent to.
label: BODY

text: Service providers can be compelled to disclose metadata and content data by law enforcement
label: BODY

text: and security agencies and judicial authorities.
label: BODY

text: Data used for non-humanitarian purposes could undermine the neutrality, impartiality
label: BODY

text: and independence of humanitarian organizations.
label: BODY

text: MALWARE OR SOCIAL ENGINEERING ATTACK
label: BODY

text: Sharing files via online conferencing tools may bypass security systems and introduce malware
label: BODY

text: into an organization’s system.
label: BODY

text: Many tools allow online conference participants to self-identify: people may not be who they say
label: BODY

text: they are.
label: BODY

text: These risks are serious. Anyone using online conferencing tools should consider the following measures
label: BODY

text: to mitigate these risks.
label: BODY

text: 2. RECOMMENDATIONS
label: HH2

text: PROTECTING YOURSELF AND YOUR ORGANIZATION
label: BODY

text: Familiarize yourself with your organization’s approved online conferencing tools, their features
label: BODY

text: and settings.
label: BODY

text: Only use tools approved by your organization when initiating a conference call, and whenever
label: BODY

text: possible when calls are requested by people outside of your organization.
label: BODY

text: Only use your organization’s conferencing tools for approved/work purposes.
label: BODY

text: Be aware of your surroundings and ensure that only authorized entities can see and hear
label: BODY

text: the information shared during an online conference.
label: BODY

text: Take a risk-based approach to online conferencing and adopt increased security measures
label: BODY

text: for higher-risk calls:
label: BODY

text: – Consider what is going to be discussed (sensitive issues, personal data, operational matters,
label: BODY

text: unofficial policies or positions, information about vulnerable individuals or groups, etc.).
label: BODY

text: – If in doubt, consult your organization’s information classification framework for guidance
label: BODY

text: as to what constitutes internal, restricted and confidential information.
label: BODY

text: – For higher-risk calls, particularly those initiated by third parties using non-approved
label: BODY

text: conferencing tools, seek further advice, find a suitable alternative (such as a secure messaging
label: BODY

text: app) or be prepared to withdraw if you are concerned about information security,
label: BODY

text: data protection or confidentiality.
label: BODY

text: MAINTAINING SECURITY FOR CONFERENCE CALLS YOU INITIATE
label: BODY

text: Use only online conferencing tools that are approved, configured and verified as secure by your
label: BODY

text: organization.
label: BODY

text: Restrict access to online conferences by limiting participation to people you have invited,
label: BODY

text: or use an access code in addition to a link.
label: BODY

text: Ensure attendees keep links and codes confidential:
label: BODY

text: – If you cannot limit access to specific invitees, request that they do not share these credentials
label: BODY

text: with any other parties.
label: BODY

text: Use new invites/links/meeting rooms for every meeting.
label: BODY

text: Where a sensitive topic is being discussed, use a unique access code so that only those with the
label: BODY

text: code for that meeting can access the room.
label: BODY

text: For recurrent meetings, change the access code regularly (i.e. weekly).
label: BODY

text: Do not allow phone dial-in unless a participant cannot take part otherwise.
label: BODY

text: Monitor attendance throughout the online conference:
label: BODY

text: – Use a dashboard to keep track of who is in the room.
label: BODY

text: – Stop the call and notify all attendees if an unidentified party joins the call.
label: BODY

text: Disable any function that is not needed in a meeting:
label: BODY

text: – e.g. chat, file-sharing, recording or any other unnecessary feature.
label: BODY

text: Before anyone shares their screen, remind participants to only share the document/file/page
label: BODY

text: that is relevant, rather than their whole screen.
label: BODY

text: Do not record meetings unless:
label: BODY

text: – this is necessary for a predefined purpose
label: BODY

text: – all participants are informed and agree
label: BODY

text: – recordings will be stored securely, encrypted using password protection, and deleted when
label: BODY

text: no longer needed.
label: BODY

text: Where available, use the “waiting room”/“green room” function to ensure that:
label: BODY

text: – a meeting cannot begin until the host has joined
label: BODY

text: – attendees cannot enter until the host approves them.
label: BODY

text: Identify all attendees before opening the lines and allowing them to join the call:
label: BODY

text: – use one-time pins, identifier codes or other means to identify attendees.
label: BODY

text: Lock the call once you have identified all attendees and lines in use.
label: BODY

text: Once a call ends, do not stay on the call to have a follow-up or side conversation as the meeting
label: BODY

text: can easily be rejoined by those who left.
label: BODY

text: MAINTAINING SECURITY FOR CONFERENCE CALLS INITIATED BY PERSONS
label: BODY

text: OUTSIDE YOUR ORGANIZATION
label: BODY

text: Take a risk-based approach by considering:
label: BODY

text: – whether the subject matter to be discussed is classified or sensitive
label: BODY

text: – the situation and security risks facing the organization that has invited you
label: BODY

text: – any risks posed by other invitees.
label: BODY

text: If you are concerned about the security of the call or the tool being used:
label: BODY

text: – discuss this in advance with the host
label: BODY

text: – request a pin or access code if none have been issued
label: BODY

text: – consider inviting them to use your organization’s approved tool.
label: BODY

text: If the concerns you raise are not addressed or mitigated, do not take part and do not disclose
label: BODY

text: any information that is not in the public realm.
label: BODY

text: At the beginning of the meeting, check whether the call will be recorded.
label: BODY

text: Throughout the call, monitor the dashboard of participants to ensure no uninvited parties are
label: BODY

text: attending.
label: BODY
